unit_title: Review of 1D Kinematics: Recap of One-Dimensional Motion Concepts
subject: Physics
expanded_description: Comprehensive review of one-dimensional motion concepts including equations of motion, uniform and non-uniform velocity, average velocity calculations, and motion under gravity with acceleration due to gravity.

core_concept.principle: One-dimensional kinematics describes motion along a straight line using position, displacement, velocity, and acceleration, with the fundamental equations $v = u + at$, $s = ut + \frac{1}{2}at^2$, and $v^2 = u^2 + 2as$ governing motion under constant acceleration.
core_concept.explanation: These relationships provide the mathematical foundation for analyzing all straight-line motion, from simple constant velocity movement to complex acceleration scenarios including free fall under gravity.

image.alt: Graphs showing position-time, velocity-time, and acceleration-time relationships for 1D motion
image.caption: Kinematics relationships: position-time graphs show displacement, velocity-time graphs show acceleration as slope and displacement as area, and acceleration-time graphs show constant acceleration for motion under gravity.

sections.introduction: Kinematics provides the language and mathematics to describe motion without considering its causes, with one-dimensional motion serving as the essential foundation for understanding more complex movement in two and three dimensions.

image.alt: Diagram showing position, displacement, velocity and acceleration vectors
image.caption: The fundamental kinematic quantities: position (x), displacement (Δx), velocity (v), and acceleration (a)

key_concept.definition: The core kinematic quantities are position ($x$), displacement ($\Delta x$), velocity ($v = \frac{dx}{dt}$), and acceleration ($a = \frac{dv}{dt}$), with average velocity $v_{avg} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}$ and instantaneous velocity describing motion at specific moments.
key_concept.context: These fundamental definitions and relationships enable precise description and prediction of motion in everything from everyday objects to celestial bodies.

image.alt: Visual representation of kinematic quantities on a motion diagram
image.caption: Relationship between position, velocity, and acceleration in one-dimensional motion

worked_examples.title: Displacement vs Distance Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A car travels 8 km north, then turns around and travels 3 km south. Calculate (a) the total distance traveled and (b) the displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: Segment 1: 8 km north, Segment 2: 3 km south
Distance is total path length = 8 km + 3 km = 11 km
Displacement is net position change = final position - initial position
step_by_step.calculation: 8 km north - 3 km south = 5 km north

worked_examples.concept_applied: Distance is scalar (magnitude only), displacement is vector (magnitude and direction)

image.alt: Diagram showing car path with distance and displacement vectors
image.caption: Visual representation: total distance (11 km) vs net displacement (5 km north)

worked_examples.title: Average Velocity Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A runner completes one lap around a 400 m circular track in 50 seconds. What is their average velocity?

step_by_step.explanation: One lap returns to starting point
Since they return to start, displacement = 0 m

worked_examples.concept_applied: Average velocity depends on displacement, not total distance

image.alt: Runner on circular track showing zero displacement
image.caption: Complete lap: distance = 400 m, but displacement = 0 m

principles.statement: Displacement is a vector quantity representing change in position ($\Delta x = x_f - x_i$), while distance is a scalar representing total path length traveled, with displacement determining net position change
principles.application: This distinction explains why round trips have zero displacement but positive distance, and determines direction in motion analysis
principles.example: Walking 100 m east then 50 m west gives 150 m distance but only 50 m east displacement
principles.analogy: Like net profit vs total revenue - displacement shows net change while distance shows total activity

sections.section_title: 2. Equations of Motion and Mathematical Framework
sections.introduction: The kinematic equations provide complete mathematical description of motion under constant acceleration, enabling prediction of position, velocity, and acceleration relationships for any time during motion.

image.alt: The four kinematic equations displayed with variable definitions
image.caption: Complete set of kinematic equations for constant acceleration motion

key_concept.definition: The four kinematic equations for constant acceleration are: (1) $v = u + at$, (2) $s = ut + \frac{1}{2}at^2$, (3) $v^2 = u^2 + 2as$, and (4) $s = \frac{(u + v)}{2}t$, where u is initial velocity, v is final velocity, a is acceleration, s is displacement, and t is time.
key_concept.context: These equations form the essential toolkit for solving all constant acceleration problems, from simple horizontal motion to complex projectile motion components.

image.alt: Graphical derivation of kinematic equations from velocity-time graph
image.caption: Kinematic equations derived from area under velocity-time graph and geometric relationships

worked_examples.title: Car Acceleration Problem
worked_examples.problem: A car accelerates from 20 m/s to 35 m/s over a distance of 200 m. Find (a) the acceleration and (b) the time taken.

step_by_step.step: Find time using v = u + at

image.alt: Velocity-time graph for accelerating car
image.caption: Car accelerates uniformly from 20 m/s to 35 m/s over 7.27 seconds

worked_examples.title: Braking Distance Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A car traveling at 25 m/s brakes and comes to rest in 80 m. Calculate the deceleration and braking time.

step_by_step.step: Find time using s = ½(u + v)t

image.alt: Velocity-time graph showing linear deceleration to rest
image.caption: Braking produces constant deceleration: velocity decreases linearly to zero

classifications.behavior: Different kinematic equations solve for different unknown quantities based on given information, with systematic approach ensuring correct solutions

examples.explanation: Choose the equation containing three known variables and one unknown. For time-independent problems, use v² = u² + 2as

image.alt: Decision tree for selecting appropriate kinematic equation
image.caption: Flowchart showing which equation to use based on known and unknown variables

examples.explanation: Establish positive direction (usually upward or forward), then assign signs consistently: positive for motion in positive direction, negative for opposite

image.alt: Coordinate system showing positive and negative directions
image.caption: Consistent sign convention: upward/rightward positive, downward/leftward negative

classifications.note: Always list known variables first, identify which equation contains exactly one unknown, and maintain consistent units throughout

sections.section_title: 3. Uniform vs Non-uniform Velocity and Acceleration
sections.introduction: Understanding the distinction between uniform and accelerated motion is crucial for selecting appropriate analysis methods, with uniform motion following simple linear relationships while accelerated motion requires the full kinematic equations.

image.alt: Comparison graphs of uniform and accelerated motion
image.caption: Uniform motion: straight line on position-time graph; Non-uniform motion: curved line showing acceleration

key_concept.definition: Uniform velocity motion has constant speed and direction ($a = 0$), described by $s = vt$, while non-uniform velocity involves acceleration ($a \neq 0$) requiring the full kinematic equations, with average velocity $v_{avg} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}$ providing useful simplification for complex motion.
key_concept.context: This distinction determines mathematical approach and explains why different motion types require different analytical tools and graphical interpretations.

image.alt: Side-by-side graphs comparing uniform and non-uniform velocity
image.caption: Left: uniform velocity (horizontal line on v-t graph); Right: non-uniform velocity (sloped line showing acceleration)

worked_examples.title: Average Velocity in Changing Motion
worked_examples.problem: A bus travels 30 km at 40 km/h, then 60 km at 60 km/h. Calculate the average velocity for the entire trip.

step_by_step.explanation: Total distance = 30 + 60 = 90 km, Total time = 0.75 + 1.0 = 1.75 h

image.alt: Position-time graph showing two different slopes for two journey segments
image.caption: Two-segment journey: steeper slope in second segment due to higher speed

worked_examples.title: Graphical Analysis of Motion
worked_examples.problem: From the velocity-time graph showing a car accelerating from 0 to 30 m/s in 10 s, then maintaining constant speed for 20 s, then decelerating to stop in 5 s, calculate the total displacement.

step_by_step.step: Calculate area under v-t graph (acceleration phase)
step_by_step.explanation: Triangle area = ½ × base × height = ½ × 10 × 30
Total displacement = sum of all areas

worked_examples.concept_applied: Displacement equals area under velocity-time graph

image.alt: Velocity-time graph with three distinct regions: acceleration, constant, deceleration
image.caption: Three-phase motion: acceleration (triangle), constant velocity (rectangle), deceleration (triangle)

examples.explanation: Car maintains constant 100 km/h on highway: a = 0, resulting in uniform motion with s = vt

examples.explanation: Person standing on moving escalator experiences constant velocity motion, traveling equal distances in equal time intervals

categories.description: Properties and analysis of accelerated motion

sections.section_title: 4. Motion Under Gravity and Free Fall
sections.introduction: Motion under constant gravitational acceleration provides the most important application of kinematic equations, with free fall demonstrating perfect constant acceleration motion and serving as the prototype for all acceleration analysis.

image.alt: Multiple exposure photograph showing falling object with equal time intervals
image.caption: Free fall motion: object accelerates downward at constant rate g = 9.8 m/s²

key_concept.definition: Motion under gravity near Earth's surface experiences constant downward acceleration $g = 9.8$ m/s² (approximately 10 m/s² for estimation), with all kinematic equations applying using $a = -g$ for upward positive coordinate systems.
key_concept.context: This special case of constant acceleration enables precise prediction of falling objects, projectile motion, and forms the foundation for understanding gravitational effects in physics.

image.alt: Vector diagram showing g pointing downward regardless of motion direction
image.caption: Gravitational acceleration g always points downward, whether object is rising, falling, or at peak

worked_examples.title: Free Fall from Height
worked_examples.problem: A stone is dropped from a cliff 80 m high. Calculate (a) time to hit ground and (b) impact velocity.

step_by_step.explanation: Upward positive, so a = -g = -9.8 m/s², s = -80 m, u = 0

step_by_step.step: Use s = ut + ½at² to find time
Use v = u + at to find impact velocity

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Time = 4.04 s, (b) Impact velocity = 39.6 m/s downward
worked_examples.concept_applied: Free fall with constant acceleration g

image.alt: Diagram showing stone falling from cliff with velocity vectors increasing
image.caption: Stone accelerates downward: velocity increases uniformly with time

worked_examples.title: Vertical Projection Upward
worked_examples.problem: A ball is thrown vertically upward with 25 m/s. Find (a) maximum height and (b) total time in air.

step_by_step.explanation: Use v = u + at with v = 0

step_by_step.step: Total time in air is twice time to max height

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Maximum height = 31.89 m, (b) Total time = 5.10 s

image.alt: Parabolic trajectory showing ball thrown upward and returning to ground
image.caption: Symmetric motion: time up equals time down, launch speed equals landing speed

worked_examples.title: Object Thrown Downward
worked_examples.problem: A ball is thrown downward from 50 m height with 15 m/s initial velocity. Find impact velocity and time.

step_by_step.explanation: u = -15 m/s (downward), s = -50 m, a = -9.8 m/s²

step_by_step.step: Find impact velocity using v² = u² + 2as
Find time using v = u + at

worked_examples.final_answer: Impact velocity = 34.71 m/s downward, Time = 2.01 s
worked_examples.concept_applied: Motion with initial velocity under gravity

image.alt: Velocity-time graph showing linear increase in downward velocity
image.caption: Ball thrown downward: starts with initial velocity and continues accelerating

classifications.value: Different types of vertical motion under gravity
classifications.behavior: All gravity-influenced motion follows kinematic equations with a = -g, exhibiting symmetric properties for projection up and down, with identical speeds at same heights

examples.explanation: Object dropped from rest: u = 0, acceleration increases velocity uniformly downward, following v = -gt and s = -½gt²

image.alt: Linear velocity-time graph starting from zero
image.caption: Free fall from rest: velocity increases linearly from zero

examples.explanation: Ball thrown upward returns to launch height with same speed: time up equals time down, trajectories are mirror images

image.alt: Symmetric parabolic path showing equal ascent and descent times
image.caption: Perfect symmetry: launch velocity magnitude equals landing velocity magnitude

examples.explanation: For vertical projection with initial velocity u, maximum height h = u²/(2g) occurs when velocity momentarily becomes zero

image.alt: Diagram showing velocity decreasing to zero at peak height
image.caption: At maximum height: velocity = 0, then motion reverses direction

classifications.note: Always define coordinate system clearly: if upward is positive, then g = -9.8 m/s²; all velocities and displacements follow this convention

summary: 1D kinematics describes motion along a straight line using position, displacement, velocity, and acceleration. The fundamental kinematic equations for constant acceleration are: $v = u + at$, $s = ut + \frac{1}{2}at^2$, $v^2 = u^2 + 2as$, and $s = \frac{u+v}{2}t$. Uniform velocity motion ($a = 0$) follows $s = vt$, while non-uniform motion requires the full equations. Average velocity $v_{avg} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}$ simplifies complex motion analysis. Motion under gravity represents constant acceleration $a = -g = -9.8$ m/s² (with upward positive), with free fall from rest following $v = -gt$ and $s = -\frac{1}{2}gt^2$. Vertical projection upward shows symmetric motion with maximum height $h_{max} = \frac{u^2}{2g}$ and time to maximum height $t = \frac{u}{g}$. Graphical analysis provides powerful tools: slope of position-time gives velocity, slope of velocity-time gives acceleration, and area under velocity-time gives displacement.
